tired.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: feeling that you want to sleep or rest
tired.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: ‘No, ’ Frank said in a tired voice.
I’m so tired I could sleep for a week.
He was too tired to argue.
tired.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: GRAMMAR: Prepositions with tired
tired.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0: If you are tired of doing something, you do not want to do it anymore because it has started to annoy or bore you
tired.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1: If you are tired from doing something, you feel tired because you have used a lot of effort
He was tired from walking all day
He was tired of walking all day
tired.translation[0].note_box[1].section: tired
feeling that you want to sleep or rest
I was really tired the next day.
the tired faces of the children
I was exhausted after the long trip home.
He sat down, exhausted.
She immediately fell into an exhausted sleep.
worn out
very tired because you have been working hard
With three small children to care for, she was always worn out.
weary
tired because you have been travelling, worrying, or doing something for a long time
weary travellers
a weary sigh
He looks tired and weary after 20 years in office.
fatigued
They were too fatigued to continue with the climb.
Because of her illness, she often became fatigued.
drained
very tired and feeling as if all your energy has gone
Afterwards, he felt drained, both physically and mentally.
bushed/beat
I’m bushed. I think I’ll go to bed early.
I’m beat. I don’t think I’ll go for a run tonight.
knackered
very tired. Knackered is a very informal use – do not use it in polite conversation
By the time I got home I was absolutely knackered.
shattered
When I first started teaching, I came home shattered every night.
extremely tired, so that you cannot do anything but sleep
I was absolutely dead by the time I got home.
almost asleep
sleepy
wanting to sleep very soon, so that your eyes start to close
I’m feeling quite sleepy. I think I’ll go to bed.
She rubbed her sleepy eyes.
drowsy
starting to sleep because you are in a warm place, have drunk too much alcohol, or have taken medicine
The tablets can make you feel drowsy.
She was beginning to feel a little drowsy after all the food and wine she had consumed.
can’t keep your eyes open/can hardly keep your eyes open
to feel so tired that you find it difficult to stay awake
I’d better get some rest – I can’t keep my eyes open.
He had been driving all night, and he could hardly keep his eyes open.
